answers.author: Richard Brown
answers.text:
Libraries have become community centers that serve a wide variety of needs in their cities and towns.  During emergencies they can serve as gathering points for friends and families and may serve to help in the dissemination of public information.  In our day to day activities we use our libraries as the sites for blood drives and cooling centers during hot weather; so their use as "medical" facilities is well established.
Additionally, since libraries have computers and internet access; they have added  value in the disaster recovery process.

answers.author: Stephanie Klinkenberger
answers.text:
Our city uses the schools for emergency shelters.  The libraries participate by manning the public Information phone lines and staffing the shelters during the emergency.

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
Libraries are the hub of many communities.  It makes a lot of sense that they are included in emergency preparedness planning processes.  Our libraries have multiple internet computer access points (including wireless), kitchens and multiple meeting rooms, just to name a few resources.

answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
Recovery from a disaster is often underestimated both in terms of time as well as psychological impact to citizens. Returning a community to a state of "normalcy" as quickly as possible enables those victimized by the event to move on with life decisions. 
A program developed in coordination with the National League of Cities and the Federal Emergency Management Agency, "Crisis Leadership for Local Government Officials," identified libraries as a key (and often overlooked) resource for cities. Libraries are used to dealing with children as well as adults and the resource can be used to occupy the time that may be spent in shelter or out of homes. Librarians are also good at managing data and can assist communities in a variety of functions both during the disaster as well as through recovery. 
If schools are closed, young people need activities by which to minimize the trauma associated with the disaster. Libraries can be a key to learning as well as overcoming that trauma.

author: Molly Leitao
text:
FEMA is proposing to include libraries and other private non-profit facilities that demonstrate they provide eligible health and safety services as eligible facilities for temporary relocation.  Do you see a value for libraries in disaster recovery?
FEMA is accepting comments on http://www.regulations.gov ID FEMA-2010-0023 until June 1, 2010.
title: What is the role of libraries in disaster response and recovery?
